Name: CYCLOATE
Description: Cycloate is a primary aliphatic amine.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Tomlin CDS, ed. Cycloate (1134-23-2). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition Version 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council. (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 190 was calculated for cycloate(SRC), using a log Kow of 3.88(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high, provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Casida JF et al; Sci 184: 573-4 (1974) (2) Novick NJ, Alexander M; Appl Environ Microbiol 49: 737-43 (1985) (3) Gray RA, Weierich AJ; Proc 9th Brit Weed Conf pp. 94-101 (1968) (4) Czulakow SA, Zarasow SU; Rocz Gllebozn 26: 179-84 (1975) (5) Skipper HD et al; Weed Technol 10: 174-90 (1996) (6) USEPA/OPPTS; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database on Cycloate (1134-23-2). USEPA 738-R-04-014, Sept, 2004. Available from the Database Query page at https://www.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/status.htm as of May 7, 2008.
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Thiocarbamates, such as cycloate, undergo rapid biodegradation(1,4). Cycloate was not mineralized in sewage or lakewater, but it was metabolized to organic products(2). When incorporated 3 inches deep into moist loam at a temperature of 70-80 °C, an 83% loss of cycloate occurred in 70 days; at 40 °C only 32% loss occurred(3). In dry soil incubated at 70-80 °C, only 9% loss occurred(3). Autoclaving the soils greatly increased the persistence of cycloate indicating that microbial degradation is important(3). Cycloate does not decrease the number or biochemical activity of soil organisms(4). Using a continuous flow-through system and soil inoculum, 14C-labeled cycloate was up to 90% mineralized(5). Laboratory metabolism study using aerobic soil resulted in a half-life of 43 days; soil degradates include the sulfoxide and N-ethylcyclohexylamine, N-cyclohexyl-N-ethylformamide and N-ethyl-N-formyl-S- ethyl thiocarbamate(6).

environmental_biodegradations.References: Kearney, P.C., and D. D. Kaufman (eds.) Herbicides: Chemistry, Degredation and Mode of Action. Volumes 1 and 2. 2nd ed. New York: Marcel Dekker, Inc., 1975., p. 338
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ... DISAPPEARANCE OF ... CYCLOATE ... FROM NONAUTOCLAVED SOIL WAS MUCH FASTER THAN FROM AUTOCLAVED SOIL. TO ASCERTAIN WHETHER DISAPPEARANCE...IS DUE SOLELY TO MICROBIAL BREAKDOWN & NOT VOLATILIZATION ... STORED SAMPLES IN SEALED CONTAINERS. RATE OF DECOMP ... 20% IN AUTOCLAVED SOIL & 60% IN NONAUTOCLAVED SOIL AFTER 3 MO OF STORAGE. ISOLATION OR IDENTIFICATION OF SOIL MICROORGANISMS CAPABLE OF DEGRADING THIOCARBAMATE & DITHIOCARBAMATE HERBICIDES HAS NOT BEEN REPORTED, NOR HAS ... MECHANISM OF MICROBIAL DEGRADATION BEEN DETERMINED. ... THIOCARBAMATE MOLECULE IS PROBABLY HYDROLYZED @ ESTER LINKAGE WITH FORMATION OF MERCAPTAN, CO2, & AMINE ... .

environmental_biodegradations.Value: MICROBIAL BREAKDOWN IS RESPONSIBLE FOR A LARGE PART OF THE DISAPPEARANCE ... FROM SOILS WHEN INCORPORATED IN THE SOIL TO A DEPTH OF 2-3 IN.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) USEPA/OPPTS; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database on Cycloate (1134-23-2). USEA 738-R-04-014, Sept, 2004. Available from the Database Query page at https://www.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/status.htm as of May 7, 2008.
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: Laboratory metabolism study using anaerobic soil resulted in a half-life of 68 days and 192 days using anaerobic aquatic system(1).

logP.References: Tomlin CDS, ed. Cycloate (1134-23-2). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition Version 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Hamaker JW, Thompson JM; Organic Chemicals in the Soil Environment. Goring, CAI, Hamaker JN, eds. 1: 49-144 (1972) (2) Kenaga EE; Ecotox Environ Safety 4:26-38 (1980) (3) USEPA/OPPTS; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database on Cycloate (1134-23-2). USEPA 738-R-04-014, Sept, 2004. Available from the Database Query page at https://www.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/status.htm as of May 7, 2008. (4) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) (5) Gray RA, Weierich AJ; Proc 9th Brit Weed Conf pp. 94-101 (1968)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of cycloate has been experimentally determined to be 345(1,2). The compound tends to sorb to soil under dry conditions and is not reversed if soil is later flooded(3). If already flooded, then cycloate desorbs readily and then volatilizes. Koc values of 500-800 have been reported(3). According to a classification scheme(4), these Koc values suggest that cycloate is expected to have moderate mobility in soil. Cycloate was found at a maximum depth of 6-9 inches in a leaching study using four different soils(5).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: Ahrens, W.H. Herbicide Handbook of the Weed Science Society of America. 7th ed. Champaign, IL: Weed Science Society of America, 1994., p. 76
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Koc 600 and Kd 9 for adsorption, and Koc 767 and Kd 11.5 for desorption in a silt loam with 1.5% organic matter; Koc 500 and Kd 10 for adsorption, and Koc 615 and Kd 12.3 for desorption in a loam with 2% organic matter; Koc 545 and Kd 2.18 for adsorption, and Koc 745 and Kd 2.87 for desorption in a sandy loam with 0.4% organic matter; Koc 678 and Kd 8.13 for adsorption, and Koc 803 and Kd 9.63 for desorption in a clay loam with 1.2% organic matter
